IUU8R9nT.question:
ATC request you to do routine AIREPS every hour.
You encounter turbulence, the passengers are restrained by their seatbelts.
Your next AIREP is due shortly. What action must you take?

options.text: Omit the routine report and submit a special AIREP.
Report the turbulence in your next AIREP.
As this is only moderate turbulence a report is not required.
Make a special AIREP and include the moderate turbulence in your next AIREP.

options.text: ...  -  .-.

9lZ5mnAn.question: During a flight you encounter a thunderstorm which is embedded in other clouds. You:

options.text: report it as soon as possible, by reporting it as a special air-report.
do not need to report it.
should report it together with your next scheduled routine metrological report.
report this information after landing at your destination.

sIPRa7fv.question: Isolated CBs have been forecast along the planned route. An aircraft flying in a layer of nimbostratus clouds and the pilots see a lightning flash. What actions should they take?

options.text: Transmit a Special-Air-Report because the CB is embedded.
Nothing, because the CBs have been forecast.
Report the lightning flash at the next waypoint, which is only 15 minutes away.
Declare a PAN as the aircraft has flown into a storm.

8HohOnz5.question: Air Traffic Control may require an aircraft to make routine meteorological reports of air temperature, wind direction and speed, and any icing or turbulence experienced.Aircraft without data link communication equipment are..

options.text: exempt from the need to make such reports unless specifically required by ATC.
expected to report only once, immediately after the request.
required to report at a normal ATS reporting point, approximately every 30 minutes.
obliged to report every 30 minutes, regardless of the aircraft’s position.

mDfAhKZG.question: Air Traffic Control may require an aircraft to make routine meteorological reports of air temperature, wind direction and speed, and any icing or turbulence experienced. Aircraft without data link communication equipment are...

options.text: exempt from the need to make such reports unless specifically required by ATC.
required to report at a normal ATS reporting point, approximately every 30 minutes.
expected to report only once, immediately after the request.
obliged to report every 30 minutes, regardless of the aircraft's position.

e62D5hKA.question:
An aircraft that encounters certain meteorological phenomena in flight must make a special report
	Which of the following must be reported?

options.text: A heavy sandstorm seen some distance from track.
An isolated thunderstorm seen close to track.
Light turbulence experienced by the aircraft.
Light icing experienced by the aircraft.

zRpwWnkv.question: What should a pilot report during an IFR flight (weather conditions / phenomena)?

options.text: A heavy sandstorm in the vicinity but not on the track.
Light icing.
An isolated thunderstorm affecting the track.
Any turbulence.

0bJ74q5y.question: When air-ground data link is used, automated routine observations should be made (reports of air temperature, wind and turbulence). Aircraft not equipped with air-ground data link equipment are:

options.text: exempt to make regular reports, unless specifically requested by ATC.
are only required to make reports upon passing reporting points, not more than 30 minutes every time.
required only to report once, immediately after being requested.
are required to make regular reports, regardless of position.

Z4EkgzOI.question: Transmissions for VHF communications propagate mainly as..

options.text: amplitude-modulated direct waves.
frequency-modulated direct waves.
amplitude-modulated surface waves.
frequency-modulated surface waves.

V77Qkx2P.question: The route forecast included the chance of isolated thunderstorms. While flying in nimbostratus clouds, the pilot sees a flash of lightning. What communication, if any, should the pilot make to ATS?

options.text: A special observation report should be made because the pilot has encountered an embedded thunderstorm.
A PAN call on the frequency in use should be made because the pilots' message is urgent.
The observation report can be omitted because thunderstorms were forecast.
The pilot should include the information in the next position report, which is due in 15 min.

tMf8mOdv.question: What do morse code identifiers of radio navigation aids consist of?

options.text: Consist of 2 to 3 letters and are given as dots and dashes.
3 letters only and the full name is given.
2 letters and are given as Latin characters.
1 to 4 letters and are given as dots and dashes.

xxrM8ciw.question: The pilot of an aircraft during an approach to land reports severe turbulence between FL 100 and FL 70. This would be classified as...

options.text: a special aircraft observation.
a pilot aftercast observation.
a routine weather observation.
an other non-routine aircraft observation.

options.text: Volcanic eruption seen in the distance
Light icing

dfFmxquk.question: VHF is the radio frequency range from..

options.text: 30 to 300 MHz.
3 to 30 MHz.

f7gIakYB.question:
Atmospheric attenuation of VHF radio transmissions is affected by the characteristics of the transmission and of the air through which it travels
Attenuation increases as :

options.text: Air temperature decreases and frequency increases.
Air temperature increases and frequency decreases.
Both air temperature and frequency decrease.
Both Air temperature and frequency increase.

73o99LfN.question:
ATC request the pilot to do routine AIREPS every hour. He/she encounters turbulence, the passengers are restrained by their seatbelts. 
 His/her next AIREP is due shortly. What action must he/she take?

options.text: Omit the routine report and submit a special AIREP.
Report the turbulence in your next AIREP.
As this is only moderate turbulence a report is not required.
Make a special AIREP and include the moderate turbulence in your next AIREP.

frequency increases and air density decreases.

air density and frequency both decrease.

FMjC7jb0.question: Atmospheric attenuation of VHF radio transmissions is affected by the characteristics of the transmission and of the air through which it travels. Attenuation increases as..

options.text: air density increases and wavelength decreases.
wavelength increases and air density decreases.

air density and wavelength both decrease.

XfJlNIcq.question: Atmospheric attenuation of VHF radio transmissions is affected by the characteristics of the transmission and of the air through which it travels. Given a stable, non-changing air pressure, attenuation increases as..

options.text: frequency increases and air temperature decreases.
air temperature and frequency both decrease.
air temperature increases and frequency decreases.
frequency and air temperature both increase.

Io6XLk9g.question: An aircraft in flight encounters an isolated thunderstorm that is obscured by other cloud. The aircraft does not encounter hail. Must this be reported and if so, when?

options.text: Yes, as soon as possible in a special report.
Yes, in the aircraft`s next routine meteorological report.
There is no requirement to report such a thunderstorm.
Yes, after landing.

4rbGLDxG.question: An aircraft in flight encounters an isolated thunderstorm that is obscured by other cloud. The aircraft does not encounter hail. Must this be reported and if so, when?

options.text: Yes, as soon as possible in a special report.
Yes, after landing.
There is no requirement to report such a thunderstorm.
Yes, in the aircraft's next routine meteorological report.

UxNRdrow.question: An aircraft in flight encounters an isolated thunderstorm that is obscured by other cloud. The aircraft does not encounter hail. Must this be reported, and if so, when?

options.text: Yes, as soon as possible in a special report.
Yes, in the aircraft's next routine meteorological report.
Yes, after landing.
There is no requirement to report such a thunderstorm.

pke3gIpf.question: The route forecast included the chance of isolated thunderstorms. While flying in nimbostratus cloud, the pilot sees a flash of lightning. What communication, if any, should the pilot make to Air Traffic Services?

options.text: A special observation report because the pilot has encountered an embedded thunderstorm.
The pilot should include the information in the next position report, which is due in 15 minutes.
A PAN call on the frequency in use because the pilot`s message is urgent.
The observation report can be omitted because thunderstorms were forecast.

5WWvnTiv.question: When would a METAR cause an immediate update to an ATIS?

options.text: Upon receipt of a METAR SPECI
Upon receipt of any official weather, regardless of content change or reported values.
Only when the ceiling and/or visibility changes by a reportable value.
Every 30 minutes if weather conditions are below those for VFR ; otherwise hourly.

Light icing.
Isolated CB's that have not been forecast.

options.text: Submit a special air report.
Not do anything, because only embedded thunderstorms require a special report.
Make a PAN call on their active frequency as this is an urgent message; other aircraft are possibly threatened by the thunderstorm.
Report the encounter in the next routine meteorological report.

179 NM
